name: Spain

Media.evidence: I would say that the most significant aspect is that the owner of Qiaosheng News, from Spain is also Vicepresident of the World Chinese Media. The media outlets are few but apparently significant.
I could find no journalist or media organization in Spain that are members of any Belt and Road news initiative.

I have not found evidence of Spanish media or journalists tours paid by China though there are many schollarship opportunities. In 2019 ABC director visited China in what seems to be an all expenses paid tour (see the URL below). But it is worth noting this is hard to find proof of.
I found no evidence but due to the large number of schollarships and the presence of  PRC related media in Spain I would doubt it.
Mainstream media in Spain use the information provided by international news agencies and only sometimes and on politically irrelevant matters, use information or footage provided by PRC state-media.
There are not many media outlets wholly or partly owned by PRC citizens and in many cases it is really hard to find evidence. But I found some quite significant.
Media.note: Media Group with strong relations with China. Director of Radio Inter is Liao Lim.

Media.evidence: Many mainstream media use contents provided by PRC state-fund media. RTVE even signed an agreement with CCTV to share content but that was in 2009 (see URL4 below).
Media.note: In the first URL, La Vanguardia quotes Associated Press (AP) but the reason this URL is included is because it portrais a video provided by Xinhua Videos that looks more like a promotion video that an actual news.

Media.evidence: The most important newspaper in Spain has a China Watch (provided by China Daily) insert. As showed in this article "Todo lo que necesitan saber sobre China, por gentileza de ‘El País’" (see URL1 below) during 2021 El Pais published an insert (it is not clear for how long) provided by China Daily. The website that portrais "Chinawatch" (see URL2 below) seems to be out of work but if you go into the articles you will see the sections are updated until July 2022 (see URL3 below). It is worth noting that El País is the most important newspaper in Spain and a highly respected and followed paper in Latin America as whole. Thus the rating.
Most important media outlets in Spain have correspondants in PRC, and many of them have denounced some kind of pressure.

Media.note: There might have been some cases but I could find no evidence.

Media.evidence: Though sort of isolated, this case was really controversial and got relevance in the public discussion in Spain.

Foreign Policy.evidence: Though there was one established in 2009, the Spanish Congress decided to suspend all Parliamentary friendship groups due to the economic crisis that same year.
Foreign Policy.note: Information confirmed via e-mail by the Congress.

Foreign Policy.evidence: It is worth noting that meetings were more before the pandemic but restrictions of travel I think that prevented some of them taking place. Thus the virtual meeting reference provided as reference 2.
Foreign Policy.note: Some evidence on the relationship and official meetings prior to COVID outbreak (see URL3~URL7 above).

Foreign Policy.evidence: I found no evidence of trainings to federal civil servants over the last 3 years.

There are reports stating the pressure regarding extraditions and a couple of years ago, the change of international jurisdiction, but it is hard to find evidence of pressure more than requests or certain potential economic impacts of decisions such as leaving Huawei out of 5G service in Spain. There was a change in international jurisdiction policy in 2014 and 2018 that apparently changed due to Chinese pressure (see URL3 below).
Spain never voted against Taiwan's right to participate as a member, observer or guest in WHO.
There was never a public support.
Spain holds a discreet diplomacy always aligned with the EU with regards to sensitive issues.
Spain holds a discreet diplomacy always aligned with the EU with regards to sensitive issues.
Spain holds a discreet diplomacy always aligned with the EU with regards to sensitive issues.

Academia.evidence: The most important universities have some kind of agreement with PRC related companies for research and cooperation.
Confucio Institutes are present in some of the most important and big universities in Spain.
There is the case of the region of Andalucía that has included Chinse in the curriculum. It is an isolated and minor example. Anecdotic so far.
There are not many but though they date from some years now, the case of Fundacion Alternativas and Real Instituto Elcano are important.

Aside from the participation of Chinese companies in Universities mentioned in 1 of this section it is hard to say if other think tanks receive support from PRC related entities. These are some identified. Maybe the case of Cátedra China (see URL4 below) but it is hard to say if they receive funds from PRC.
In any case there is no evidence of financial support from PRC-connected individiuals or entities to these or any think tanks or academic research centers.

Found some in previous periods but nothing since 2020.

In the interview Sentis states: ""I am extremely thankfull for the invitation by the Chinese Embassy in Spain to take part in this trip that opens new opportunities and where I was able to share interesting meetings with diplomats and experts from 23 European countries"". We do not have access to the actual payment of the trip but I am pretty sure this statement certifies that it is a paid visit. But no concrete evidence or statement declaring who paid for the trip.
On the other evidence provided, here you can find a more detailed information in this artical "La Fundación para el intercambio entre Yiwu y España presenta el ‘Viaje para descubrir el tren Madrid - Yiwu’" (see URL1 below) . I could not find specific information on who was paying for this trip but this article states that it is an initiative by local government of Yiwu
Before the analyzed period there was this case "Beijing accused of pressuring Spanish university to drop Taiwanese cultural event" (see the URL below).
Before the analyzed period there was this case "Una supuesta coacción de China a la Universidad de Salamanca genera gran tensión" (see the URL below).

Domestic Politics.evidence: They are not so many but they are from important cities in the country.
There has been some paid trips to leaders of PP but it dates back to 2013.
There were not so many, probably due to COVID restrictions in China, but they were relevant in terms of virtual communications.
Domestic Politics.note: Previous to the pandemic, meetings of this sort took place fluently: https://www.icex.es/icex/es/navegacion-principal/todos-nuestros-servicios/informacion-de-mercados/paises/navegacion-principal/el-pais/relaciones-bilaterales/index.html?idPais=CN

Domestic Politics.evidence: Though not opposing to a candidacy or coming from the UFWD but straight from the Embassy (see URLs below).

It is hard to say, specially because it is hard to define "positive". The government officials and political leaders usually have friendly expressions with regards to PRC and rarely express their concerns on sensitive issues such as Human rigths, Taiwan, Uygurs or Tibet. Also the indicator "El presidente del Gobierno recibe a representantes de la comunidad china en España"  could be considered (see URL1 below).
I found this case of an MP who is partner in a consulting firm working in/with China.

Economy.evidence: In 2021 China was second importer in Spain but came up in the 10th place on exports.

There are no equivalent figures for China from either the Spanish or Chinese authorities. However the perception in the market is that this jurisdiction is playing a considerable and growing role in financing the Spanish Treasury in the last two years.
There are many and relevant cases.
Spain is member since 2017 with 1.8% subscription.
There is one with the European Union under consultation and study.

Technology.evidence: Telefonica and China Unicom had crossed property until a couple of years ago when Telefonica stopped having a Chinese in the board (see URL1 below).
The latest agreement I found were in 2019 and apparently the main Spanish Telcos are leaving PRCs companies behind. Those agreements still taking place are not significant.

Apparently, the presence of middleboxes is not as important as to be easily detected and there are measures in place to prevent internet constraints. But at the same time academic studies show the presence of middleboxes and websites being blocked in Spain by Spanish ISP. But they are isolated and not significant cases.
There are no restrictions that I could find evidence of in place.
I would say the case of the city of Tres Cantos in the outskirts of Madrid is significant but also seems to be quite an isolated case.
Barcelona is probably the most significant.
There are some investments but in small and insignificant cases.
There are many signifcant cases due to the importance of such companies.
TikTok ranks 3rd or 4th depending on the ranking.

Society.evidence: I could not find an official website of any of these organizations but they used to have more activities around 2016.
Evidence found prooves that Spanish trade unions tend to be critical of labor practices in the PRC.
There are really few and not very relevant.
Due to COVID there were many donations from Chinese companies, businesspeople and government but they were, in all the documented cases, donations given to the Spanish government.
Something not widespread or massively consumed.
They are actually pretty critical in particular with the restrictions in place during COVID in many PRC's cities.
Evidence show the opposite, particularly after COVID.

Military.evidence: No such incident occurred. There is a EU arms embargo on China.
No evidence found. Only in 2018 there was a shared drill in Djibouti (see the URL below)
They conducted a medical rescue drill in Djibouti with PRC.

Law Enforcement.evidence: It is a really controversial issue that comes up every now and then.
In 2018 Spain and PRC signed a joint declaration includingthe aspect of fight against terrorism but no agreement was signed on that regard.
Every now and then something related to the Chinese mafia (that is what they call it in Spain) appears in the media.
I could not find specific cases of companies accusing PRC but there is this one report that mentions this as a certain possibility without giving details.
There are many reports on this showing the significance, though there are not that many.
Found no evidence, though I know there are threats cases, not clearly linked to triads and not made public yet.
I found only these two cases of certain significance.
Spain is one of the fue Western Hemisphere countries doing it every now and then.
These decisions usually atract criticism but they do it anyway.

description-1: In 2021, Spain had a GDP per capita of US$30,116 with a total population of 47,32 million people, of which 224,559 are Chinese.
description-2: Spain established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1973. Spain was ranked 32rd in Reporters Without Borders' 2022 World Press Freedom Index, and was rated Free in Freedom House's 2022 Global Freedom Status, with a score of 90/100.
